At the annual opening reception
of the Young Men's Christian Association on Friday night in Levering Hall, President Goodnow made
his first appearance before the undergraduates, winning immediate
favor by announcing himself a convert to athletics.
Everyone rose when Dr. Goodnow was presented, greeting him
with a round of applause that was
exceeded only by the one accorded
him when he expressed his approval
of college athletics. He told the
men that his opposition to sports,
which it had taken thirty years to
cultivate, was wiped away entirel
when he saw the good results ohtamed by athletics last year in giving the young men of China, where
organized sports are entirely new,

By COACH JOHN M. CATES.
Johns Hopkins won its opening
game of the 1914 football season on
Saturday by defeating Stevens Institute 16 to 13. The day was much
too hot for football, but in spite of
this the teams stood up remarkably
well. Owing to the limited preliminary practice, Hopkins was not
in as good physical condition as
Stevens, and frequent substitutions
were necessary. At the beginning
of the third period, almost an entirely new team was sent in. It
was hoped that the substitutes
could hold their own while the first
string men were resting. At the
outset, they more than held their
own. A particularly good tackle
caused the Stevens man to fumble
the ball on the kick-off. "Jack"
Branham was on the job, and after
recovering the ball on a lucky
bound, ran with good interference
for a touchdown. This was admittedly a flukey score, but the same
was true of Stevens' second touchdown. The second string men
were confused on signals and an
unexcusable fumble on Stevens' 40yard line resulted in the recovery
of the ball by Stevens' leftend, who
ran sixty yards for a touchdown.
Leaving out these two scores, the
score would otherwise indicate the
respective merits of the teams.
Hopkins scored first on a series
of plays just off tackle. Uhler,
aided by "Joe" Branham's splendid interference, broke through for
a 35-yard run to the goal line.
Following a penalty for roughness
against Hopkins, Stevens was given
the ball on Hopkins' 20-yard line,
making first down. The line held
splendidly. Failing ,to gain by
rushing, Stevens executed a perfect
forward pass for a score. With
the score a tie at 13, all the first
string backs were again sent in.
They carried the ball to the 20-yard
line, where an attempted drop-kick
failed.
After the touchback, Hopkins
again carried the ball to the 30yard line. Failing to gain by rushing, Wilkinson kicked a beautiful
goal from placement. This ended
the scoring.
For a first game, remarkably few
fumbles were made. Some faults
were developed, but none of a glaring nature. The line for the most
part played well. The tackling was
good in spots. It is not our intention to single out individual men as
recipients of praise. We expect
every man to play well. When
every man does that the team as

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 12, 1914.
SEVEN MEN AT EAGLES MERE

SUTTON PLANS FOR BUSY YEAR

Hopkins Representation at Religious
Conference Enjoyed Meetings and
Athletics—Uhler a Track Star.

Y. M. C. A. Will Make Its Force Felt
Through a Series of Meetings, Daily
Chapel and Bible Classes.

About four hundred students of
a majority of the colleges of the
South Atlantic States attended the
Eagles Mere Conference, at Eagles
Mere, Pa., last June. The representatives of Johns Hopkins were
Walter D. Sutton, Dr. Walter F.
Shenton, Emmette R. Spencer,
Monroe Firor, Clarence McDowell,
Alfred Niles and Claude I. Uhler.
The Bible and mission study
classes usually met in the morning
under the direction of prominent
leaders.
•
In the afternoon the time was
devoted entirely to. athletics—baseball, tennis, running, etc.—and Hopkins men showed up well. Uhler
and McDowell proved to be a
strong combination in the tennis
tournament, and got as far as the
semi-finals. Uhler was again in the
limelight in the track meet. He
scored seven points for Hopkins by
finishing second in the 220-yard
dash and third in the _quarter-mile
run. In the 220-yard event, Uhler
competed against a classy field,
beating such men as Fergerson of
the University of Pennsylvania.
The evenings were devoted to vocational meetings, at which discussions were made of the different
phases of Christian work in foreign
fields, as well as at home. At these
meetings men like John R. Mott,
the great leader of student activities; Dr. W. Douglas MacKenzie,
of the. Hartford Theological Seminary, and Dean Shailer Mathews,
of the Chicago Divinity School
thrilled the audiences with stirring
speeclies.
These summer conferences, which
are held each year just after the
close of the University, are of great
benefit to a college man and the
good times are not soon forgotten. To get an idea of these conferences ask one of the tlopkins
men who have attended them.

Over two hundred men called
last Tuesday to receive the handbooks distributed by the **Hopkins
branch of the Young Men's Christian Association to students by Secretary Walter D. Sutton. Since
then, he has been kept busy meeting the old men and making new
ones feel at home in Levering Hall
—the Association's building.
A big year is ahead for the Association, for quite a bit of work
has been planned to take place under its direction. Beginning today,
chapel services will be held in Levering Hall at 8.40 o'clock every
morning. Every student is invited
to attend—graduate students and
freshmen being especially invited.
Dean Edward H. Griffin will lead
the services this week.
A special feature this year will
be meetings conducted by a number of prominent local preachers,
among whom will be Dr. Wallace
Ferris, of Mt. Vernon M. E.
Church; Dr. W. H. Dunbar, of St.
Mark's tnglish Lutheran Church,
and Dr. R. W. Hogue, of Ascension Episcopal Church. Dr. Brush,
Dr. French and Dr. Magoffin of the
faculty will assist during the year.
Bible study classes are being
planned, and invitations will soon
be issued for students to join. There
will be three classes for upper
classmen and a class for freshmen
led by Secretary Sutton.
Arrangements will soon .be made
for the two lectures that are given
annually by Dr. J. M. T. Finney.
It is probable that these lectures
will be delivered in November.

Three Dances Scheduled for This Year.

Locker Fee Now $10.

•

The locker fee, required of all
students, has been increased from
five to ten dollars, with the approval of the trustees of the University. The old fee carried only
the privilege of holding a locker
in the gymnasium, but the new one
includes towel service and a season
ticket to all games played at Homewood in which the University teams
take part.
The new system, besides assuring a larger attendance at Homewood, saves the student the $1.50
heretofore paid for towel service.
Graduate students, although not required to pay the fee, may take
advantage of. the saving of towel
money if they buy the undegraduate season ticket.

As is the custom, there will be
three dances this year, in McCoy
Hall, under the supervision of the
Cotillon Board, to which alumni
and all those having a personal interest in the University are invited
to subscribe.
The Board has not yet selected
the dates for the cotillons. However, they will probably be held
during the early part of December,
the latter part of January, and the
early part of May,
The committee in charge promise
that all entertainments will be up

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 12, 1914.

John C. Knipp, business manager of THE NEWS-LETTER, has been
granted a leave of absence of one
year. During this time .his duties
will be looked after by C. Prevost
Boyce and William A. McKewen.
Because of the large number of
publications bearing the title'NewsLetter," this paper, to distinguish
it from others, has incorporated
the name of the University in its
title and will henceforth be called

THE
TER.

JOHNS HOPKINS' NEWS-LET-

In the news and editorial columns, however,where the references
are obvious, it will continue to be
called THE NEWS-LETTER. This is
the system followed, for example,
by The Baltimore News, it being
called simply The News where the
reference is understood. • -

THE NEWS - LETTER invites all
undergraduates, especially members
of the Class of 1918, who are interested in "college journalism" to
become candidates for the several
vacant positions on the editorial and
business staffs.
The paper is a Hopkins "activity" in the same sense as is the football team, and requires similar support. When the present editors and
business managers have been graduated their duties will be taken up
by men who are now members of
the younger classes.
As in all other activities, it is wise
to begin early, and it is with this
hint that we invite interested members of the freshman class to register their names with the editor as
candidates.
To Freshmen.

The week just past was the open
season for advice to freshmen.
Nearly all of the addresses of welcome heard by the new men were
burdened with hints of how to act

a,

and what to do. But m•,;t of this
advice was academic; it was from
the point of view of the professor.
THE NEWS-LETTER now, believing it interprets the opinion of the
Student body, wishes to emphasize
the necessity of observing some
simple requests wh:ch will help
make "better freshmen" of the new
men in the eyes of their Hopkins
colleagues.
. First of all, the "freshman regulations" issued by the Student
Council should receive united support. They should be observed by
the individual, and the class as a
whole should correct in a su:table
manner any knowing violators.
A number of upper classmen last
week noticed several instances of
disobedience of the rules, but the
violators probably were uninformed
of the contents and significance of
the code. After the first meeting
of the class, when the matter will
be explained fully and offic:ally,
there should be no excuse for further violations.
It is hardly necessary to discuss
the history of the abandonment of
hazing at Hopkins. It may be said,
briefly, however, that the upper
classes, following the lead of a majority of the larger -Eastern colleges, saw the absurdity of street
fights, immersions in the pools of
Mount Vernon Place and disagreeable climaxes of hazing parties.
After a ser:es of conferences, called
and conducted by the Student
Council, the faculty and students
approved the set of regulations
which only "public opinion" is to
enforce. The rules are sane and
conservative — simply summing up
in code old traditions which sophomores in days of old have gone into battle to enforce. Two years
ago, for instance, the pers'stence
of a freshman in wearing his derby
in McCoy Hall precipitated a fight
proportionately unequalled by anything that has yet happened along
the Aisne or at Przemysl. In those
times freshman insolence bre d
fights. The new system is obviously better, for that same insolence
will breed a "silence treatment" of
freshmen that will be even more
injurious than a torn shirt or a
darkened eye.
The system which is •being inaugurated this year has been sanet:oned by the faculty and students
after a serious study of conditions
at Hopkins, and we believe it is
only necessary to communicate this
fact to the new men to insure their
co-operation in the step toward better spirit and class feeling. •
Another suggestion THE NEWSLETTER wishes to make concerns
the noun frequently used by new
men in referring to the Johns Hopkins University. We hear such
Phrases as, "It is a fine school,"
"Have you subscribed for the school
paper yet?" etc.
Hopkins is not a school, in the
definite meaning of that word, and
the freshman who persists in calling it so appears childish in the
estimation of those who understand

and use the dignified and correct
university. Remember that vou are
college men attending a university.
The third suggestion is offered
to avoid the recurrence of the anc:ent joke- on Professor Brush.
Each year some freshman, reading
in the University circular, discovers
that the French language is taught
by Professor Brush. Immediately
he calls up a companion and tells
him it is a good thing the professor
does not teach German, for then he
would be called Herr Brush. And
then the epidemic of that "joke"
passes over the University, annoy:ng three upper classes who have
reached the sage of shedding- tears
over the words. The "joke," we
may add, is well known. It was
discoyered in 1873, and has been
told at the Maryland Theatre.
And so THE NEWS-LETTER, askng the carrying out of these reattests, bids the Class of 1918 a
hearty welcome.
Select Rhodes Scholar New Way.

A change of system in the method
of selecting the Rhodes scholars to
Oxford University has been announced to Am e r lean colleges.
Hitherto, scholars haYe been elected
in all states in two successive years,
while in each recurring third year
none was chosen. The new system
divides the forty-eight states into
groups, and the groups are to be
alternated in the presentation of
candidates. The next qualifying
examination will be held in all states
on October 5 and 6, 1915. The
scholarships carry $1,500 a year,
and are tenable for three years.

AT OTHER COLLEGES
Lehigh Practicing Lacrosse.
The Lehigh lacrosse coaches arc
holding fall practice, primarily to
teach new men the rudiments of the
game. Many of the last-year men
took advantage of this time and reported also.
These practices are to be held
every Tuesday, Wednesday and
Friday afternoon of each week and
all candidates for the team, whether
new or old, have been ordered out.
This year 'the champions of the
Intercollegiate Lacrosse League
probably will be invited by the American Amateur Athletic League to the
Panama Exposition at San Francis°. The manner of choosing the
team has not yet been decided. It
is quite evident, however, that in
order to have a chance to go, Lehigh must at least .be champions of
this division.—The Brown and
White.

Actual class, work at Homewood
began Tuesday, when the engineering faculty and -third and fourth
year students organ:zed in the new
Mechanical and Electrical Engineering Building.
There were no ceremonies, but
the handful of men who will work
there for the year felt that they
were beginning something new in
the history of the University. They
were proud of the honor of being
the first to work and study in the
new buildings on the Homewood
Estate.
The' third and fourth year technical students, numbering barely
thirty men, will be the only ones to
work there regularly. The sophomores, however, will use the drawing-rooms on Saturday mornings.
Other -tech" classes will be con
ducted in McCoy Hall and the la
boratories.
The building has not been completed in some few details of con
struction and, because of this fact.
the students Nvill derive a great
benefit in watching the installation
of heavy machinery when it arrives after the contractors have
surrendered the building to the
University. This is an advantage
that very few students of engineering have.
The building will be completed
in about two weeks, and the technical branch of the University no
longer will be a dream, but a reality.

Tilden, Thomas, Pullin, Kouwenhoven, Christie and Jones. Dr.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER

6

DR. REMSEN RETURNS

12,1914.

HIS TIMELY FIELD GOAL IN LAST MINUTE OF GAME BEAT STEVENS

Dr. Abercrombie Writes Complete Description of Gymnasium and Athletic
Work for the Alumni Magazine.

President-Emeritus of University Visited
New Zealand When War Spoiled
Interesting Australian Trip.

Dr. Ira Remsen, president-emeritus of the University, returned on
Friday night with Mrs. Remsen
from a long trip across the globe.
He started on July 22 for Australia, leaving San Francisco at the
end of the month. While on the
Pacific, however, the European war
broke out, and the sessions of the
British Association for the Advancement of Science, which he was
to have attended in Sydney, Australia, were canceled. Dr. and Mrs.
Remsen did not learn of the war
until they touched port some time
after actual fighting had begun.
As the boat they were on was
requisitioned at Wellington, New
Zealand, Dr. Remsen decided not to
go on to Australia. He remained
about a month, during which time
he saw much of the country and
had opportunity to study the people
and customs of this strange, remote
land.
"New Zealand is surprisingly up
to date," Dr. Remsen said. "It is
all quite modern, and as for war
news, well, we got plenty of it. I
find that I am about as well posted
as if I had been in the United States
all the time. The New Zealanders
are very patriotic. They, of course,
can see but one result of the war.
Interest in the conflict was intense,
and every .man seemed willing to
go to the front if necessary.
"There is a small standing army,
but I do not think it is especially
important."

TELLS OF GYMNASIUM WORK

Yell Practices This Week.

President Thomas F. Troxell, of
the General Athletic Association,
will call a mass-meeting (probably
two) this week, the object of which
is primarily to give new men practice in the Hopkins yells and songs.
The dates will be posted on the bulletin board.
The cheering stand on Saturday
did well under Leader Jack DeWitt,
but improvement will be needed.
Of course, it is impossible to expect immediate perfection in the
more complicated "figures," and for
this reason the defects of last week
may be overlooked.
One of the "freshman regulations" requires immediate mastery
of the yells and songs, and, inasmuch as the upper classmen will arrange meetings to afford practice,
it is hoped everyone will contribute
his voice to the good cause.
At the practice last week Bill
Merrick, Bob Nelson and Jack DeWitt alternated in leading the yells.

A Reminder of Hopkins Days.

Freshmen who have already begun to groan under the burden of
compulsory gymnasium work will
doubtless be interested in Dr. Abercrombie's article, "The Department
of the Gymnasium," published in
the June number of the Alumni
Illaga47ine. The history of the departrnent, its control, the position
it has occupied at -various times
M relation to the other University
units and a description of its work
are given in brief, and closely related matters of athletic interest
are then discussed.
In particular, Dr. Abercrombie
explains the machinery by which
the business of the Athletic Association is transacted. A diagram is
given, showing the relative powers
of each of the individuals or boards
connected W 1 al gymnasium and
athletic team control. Great emphasis is laid upon the fact that the
desire of the trustees and faculty
is to encourage student control of
athletic affairs, although veto power
must of necessity be given to the
faculty, through the person of the
director of the gymnasium. Under
ordinary circumstances, however,
this official acts only in the capacity
of adviser, or a court of appeals
when any dispute arises.
A paragraph .in the latter part of
the article discusses the question of
medical attention .for.those who are
seriously injured while representing the University on any athletic
team. The writer then deals with
the Hopkins policy in regard to
graduate and professional coaching,
and closes. with a list of names of
the men who compose the present
Athletic Board and management of
the teams.

HARVARD GREETS FRESH1ES

'MEDICAL SCHOOL CELEBRATES

The "Lampoon's" Story of the Opening
Reception to New Men Sounds
Very, Very Familiar.

Anniversaries Observed Last Week Bring
Host of Famous Doctors and Nurses.
Dr.Goodnow's First Appearance.

Here is the program—is hasn't
varied a jot for zoo years.
The• room is packed to suffocation with excited young men in new
shoes, all trying to look dignified,
exclusive and athletic.
Bumf (President of Student
Council)—Fellers [cheers and applause], I'm glad to see y' all.
[Fuddled sophomore in rear, who
has come in to get the refreshments, "Raise him, somebody."] I
hope you like the dear old place
[sobs] ; I hope you'll all go out
for something. [Several go out
for air.] Yes, it pays to be active;
take Blifkins, for example. [Tells
the third oldest story in captivity,
and everyone roars with laughter.]
It is now my pleasure to interduce
Captain Gumf of the Eleven. [Violent cheering.]
Captain Gumf (swallowing several lumps in quick succession)—
Fellers [mad tumult and cries of
"Hear," "Beer" and "Bravo"]—I
repeat, Fellers [another outbreak],
I'm not a speechmaker [applause],
but I-hope-we'll go-to-Nooaven-an'beatell-outa-Yale.
[Pandemonium!]
The Glee Club, which has suddenly appeared from somewhere,
and which tries to look as if it were
present by mere chance, .obliges
with the new one, "Australia, Bum,
Bum, Bum," and follows it up with
"Em, Zwei, Drei." [Modest applause.]
Bumf—Fellers, the next speaker
is Mr. Lumf, of the Crimson.
Lumf arises amid catcalls, does a
Dan'l-Webster pose, and awaits applause. He begins,"My dear young
friends [silence; several dear young
friends depart via the window]. It
is indeed a rare pleasure to see your
smiling and boyish countenances,
as yet unmarked by the cares we
editors know. I am unprepared to
do this occasion justice; I was called
upon at the last minute to come before you; so I have no speech
ready. [Consults typewritten manuscript of his speech and and proceeds.]
"This brings me to point number
two which, as I have forgotten it,
I will not consider. [Genuine ap„plause.]
"But on this happy occasion I
must tell a funny story. As I was
sitting last night in my sanctum
tankorum, making up the Crimson
[impressive but fruitless pause]
with the aid of a bottle of Bud, a
pair of shears, some paste and a
week-old Transcript, a man entered,
very excited, and asked: 'Can I
subscribe for the Crimson here?'
Quick as a flash I retorted: 'Maybe
so, and then again, maybe not.'
We both laughed heartily at my
little sally. [Pause—Lumf titters;
others remain grimly silent.]

A host of alumni of the Johns
Hopkins M edica 1 School and
Nurses' Training School returned
to Baltimore last week to take part
(in the twenty-fifth anniversary Celebration of the hospital and the
twenty-fifth anniversary of the
Medical School.
Distinguished
medical men of this country and
Europe attended the exercises, and
clinics, banquets and the Huerta
lectures added to the scientific importance of the celebration.
At a public meeting held in the
Lyric on the opening day of the
celebration, President Goodnovv
made his first public appearance in
Baltimore. In a clear and concise
address, Dr. Goodnow made an exceedingly agreeable impression upon
the audience. No reference to any
plans which he may have for his
work at the University was made.
Disappointment was expressed
because of the inability of Sir William Osler, of Oxford, honorary
professor of medicine at Hopkins,
to attend. He was detained in England on account of the war.
More than five hundred alumni of
the Medical School and more than
two hundred of the graduates of
the Training School for Nurses attended the celebration.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR—What do you think of the
following war poem?
When old von Kluck to England goes,
You'll see that land in its death throes.
He will grab the English by the collar,
And won't John Bull put up some holler!
Tommy Atkins will start on a run
When he sees in the distance the German siege gun.
Ask them in London Town today
The name of the general that will have
full sway
If Deutschland succeeds in winning the
fray;
And as one voice you will hear them
say:
"It's the wizard that led us a merry
dance
Through the hills and valleys of dear
old France.
For when we thought that he was lost
We found he had his fingers crossed,
And this old buck is Herr von Kluck!"

Yours,

L. S.

Seeing and Hearing.
"Did you see the shot fired?" was
the question of an Irishman called as
a witness in a trial once had in
Kansas City.
"I did not," was the Celt's response, "but I heard it foired."
"The evidence is not satisfactory," sternly announced the presiding magistrate. "Step down."
This legal finding was evidently
not precisely to the liking of the
Irishman, for no sooner had he left
the stand and had turned his back
than he gave way to a somewhat
derisive laugh. This had the effect
of arousing in turn the judge's ire,
and he immediately recalled the offender.
"How dare you show such contempt of court?" demanded his
honor. "What do you mean by
laughing in that manner?"
"Did your honor see me laugh?"
asked the Irishman, in a most respectful tone.
"No, but I distinctly heard you
laugh," said the magistrate.
A twinkle canie into the eyes of
the witness. "Such evidence is not
satisfactory, your honor," said he
quietly. Whereupon everyone, including the judge, laughed.

By COACH JOHN M. CATES.
Johns Hopkins won its opening
game of the 1914 football season on
Saturday by defeating Stevens Institute 16 to 13. The day was much
too hot for football, but in spite of
this the teams stood up remarkably
well. Owing to the limited preliminary practice, Hopkins was not
in as good physical condition as
Stevens, and frequent substitutions
were necessary. At the beginning
of the third period, almost an entirely new team was sent in. It
was hoped that the substitutes
could hold their own while the first
string men were resting. At the
outset, they more than held their
own. A particularly good tackle
caused the Stevens man to fumble
the ball on the kick-off. "Jack"
Branham was on the job, and after
recovering the ball on a lucky
bound, ran with good interference
for a touchdown. This was admittedly a flukey score, but the same
was true of Stevens' second touchdown. The second string men
were confused on signals and an
unexcusable fumble on Stevens' 40yard line resulted in the recovery
of the ball by Stevens' leftend, who
ran sixty yards for a touchdown.
Leaving out these two scores, the
score would otherwise indicate the
respective merits of the teams.
Hopkins scored first on a series
of plays just off tackle. Uhler,
aided by "Joe" Branham's splendid interference, broke through for
a 35-yard run to the goal line.
Following a penalty for roughness
against Hopkins, Stevens was given
the ball on Hopkins' 20-yard line,
making first down. The line held
splendidly. Failing ,to gain by
rushing, Stevens executed a perfect
forward pass for a score. With
the score a tie at 13, all the first
string backs were again sent in.
They carried the ball to the 20-yard
line, where an attempted drop-kick
failed.
After the touchback, Hopkins
again carried the ball to the 30yard line. Failing to gain by rushing, Wilkinson kicked a beautiful
goal from placement. This ended
the scoring.
For a first game, remarkably few
fumbles were made. Some faults
were developed, but none of a glaring nature. The line for the most
part played well. The tackling was
good in spots. It is not our intention to single out individual men as
recipients of praise. We expect
every man to play well. When
every man does that the team as

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 12, 1914.
SEVEN MEN AT EAGLES MERE

SUTTON PLANS FOR BUSY YEAR

Hopkins Representation at Religious
Conference Enjoyed Meetings and
Athletics—Uhler a Track Star.

Y. M. C. A. Will Make Its Force Felt
Through a Series of Meetings, Daily
Chapel and Bible Classes.

About four hundred students of
a majority of the colleges of the
South Atlantic States attended the
Eagles Mere Conference, at Eagles
Mere, Pa., last June. The representatives of Johns Hopkins were
Walter D. Sutton, Dr. Walter F.
Shenton, Emmette R. Spencer,
Monroe Firor, Clarence McDowell,
Alfred Niles and Claude I. Uhler.
The Bible and mission study
classes usually met in the morning
under the direction of prominent
leaders.
•
In the afternoon the time was
devoted entirely to. athletics—baseball, tennis, running, etc.—and Hopkins men showed up well. Uhler
and McDowell proved to be a
strong combination in the tennis
tournament, and got as far as the
semi-finals. Uhler was again in the
limelight in the track meet. He
scored seven points for Hopkins by
finishing second in the 220-yard
dash and third in the _quarter-mile
run. In the 220-yard event, Uhler
competed against a classy field,
beating such men as Fergerson of
the University of Pennsylvania.
The evenings were devoted to vocational meetings, at which discussions were made of the different
phases of Christian work in foreign
fields, as well as at home. At these
meetings men like John R. Mott,
the great leader of student activities; Dr. W. Douglas MacKenzie,
of the. Hartford Theological Seminary, and Dean Shailer Mathews,
of the Chicago Divinity School
thrilled the audiences with stirring
speeclies.
These summer conferences, which
are held each year just after the
close of the University, are of great
benefit to a college man and the
good times are not soon forgotten. To get an idea of these conferences ask one of the tlopkins
men who have attended them.

Over two hundred men called
last Tuesday to receive the handbooks distributed by the **Hopkins
branch of the Young Men's Christian Association to students by Secretary Walter D. Sutton. Since
then, he has been kept busy meeting the old men and making new
ones feel at home in Levering Hall
—the Association's building.
A big year is ahead for the Association, for quite a bit of work
has been planned to take place under its direction. Beginning today,
chapel services will be held in Levering Hall at 8.40 o'clock every
morning. Every student is invited
to attend—graduate students and
freshmen being especially invited.
Dean Edward H. Griffin will lead
the services this week.
A special feature this year will
be meetings conducted by a number of prominent local preachers,
among whom will be Dr. Wallace
Ferris, of Mt. Vernon M. E.
Church; Dr. W. H. Dunbar, of St.
Mark's tnglish Lutheran Church,
and Dr. R. W. Hogue, of Ascension Episcopal Church. Dr. Brush,
Dr. French and Dr. Magoffin of the
faculty will assist during the year.
Bible study classes are being
planned, and invitations will soon
be issued for students to join. There
will be three classes for upper
classmen and a class for freshmen
led by Secretary Sutton.
Arrangements will soon .be made
for the two lectures that are given
annually by Dr. J. M. T. Finney.
It is probable that these lectures
will be delivered in November.

Three Dances Scheduled for This Year.

Locker Fee Now $10.

•

The locker fee, required of all
students, has been increased from
five to ten dollars, with the approval of the trustees of the University. The old fee carried only
the privilege of holding a locker
in the gymnasium, but the new one
includes towel service and a season
ticket to all games played at Homewood in which the University teams
take part.
The new system, besides assuring a larger attendance at Homewood, saves the student the $1.50
heretofore paid for towel service.
Graduate students, although not required to pay the fee, may take
advantage of. the saving of towel
money if they buy the undegraduate season ticket.

As is the custom, there will be
three dances this year, in McCoy
Hall, under the supervision of the
Cotillon Board, to which alumni
and all those having a personal interest in the University are invited
to subscribe.
The Board has not yet selected
the dates for the cotillons. However, they will probably be held
during the early part of December,
the latter part of January, and the
early part of May,
The committee in charge promise
that all entertainments will be up

BALTIMORE, MD., OCT. 12, 1914.

John C. Knipp, business manager of THE NEWS-LETTER, has been
granted a leave of absence of one
year. During this time .his duties
will be looked after by C. Prevost
Boyce and William A. McKewen.
Because of the large number of
publications bearing the title'NewsLetter," this paper, to distinguish
it from others, has incorporated
the name of the University in its
title and will henceforth be called

THE
TER.

JOHNS HOPKINS' NEWS-LET-

In the news and editorial columns, however,where the references
are obvious, it will continue to be
called THE NEWS-LETTER. This is
the system followed, for example,
by The Baltimore News, it being
called simply The News where the
reference is understood. • -

THE NEWS - LETTER invites all
undergraduates, especially members
of the Class of 1918, who are interested in "college journalism" to
become candidates for the several
vacant positions on the editorial and
business staffs.
The paper is a Hopkins "activity" in the same sense as is the football team, and requires similar support. When the present editors and
business managers have been graduated their duties will be taken up
by men who are now members of
the younger classes.
As in all other activities, it is wise
to begin early, and it is with this
hint that we invite interested members of the freshman class to register their names with the editor as
candidates.
To Freshmen.

The week just past was the open
season for advice to freshmen.
Nearly all of the addresses of welcome heard by the new men were
burdened with hints of how to act

a,

and what to do. But m•,;t of this
advice was academic; it was from
the point of view of the professor.
THE NEWS-LETTER now, believing it interprets the opinion of the
Student body, wishes to emphasize
the necessity of observing some
simple requests wh:ch will help
make "better freshmen" of the new
men in the eyes of their Hopkins
colleagues.
. First of all, the "freshman regulations" issued by the Student
Council should receive united support. They should be observed by
the individual, and the class as a
whole should correct in a su:table
manner any knowing violators.
A number of upper classmen last
week noticed several instances of
disobedience of the rules, but the
violators probably were uninformed
of the contents and significance of
the code. After the first meeting
of the class, when the matter will
be explained fully and offic:ally,
there should be no excuse for further violations.
It is hardly necessary to discuss
the history of the abandonment of
hazing at Hopkins. It may be said,
briefly, however, that the upper
classes, following the lead of a majority of the larger -Eastern colleges, saw the absurdity of street
fights, immersions in the pools of
Mount Vernon Place and disagreeable climaxes of hazing parties.
After a ser:es of conferences, called
and conducted by the Student
Council, the faculty and students
approved the set of regulations
which only "public opinion" is to
enforce. The rules are sane and
conservative — simply summing up
in code old traditions which sophomores in days of old have gone into battle to enforce. Two years
ago, for instance, the pers'stence
of a freshman in wearing his derby
in McCoy Hall precipitated a fight
proportionately unequalled by anything that has yet happened along
the Aisne or at Przemysl. In those
times freshman insolence bre d
fights. The new system is obviously better, for that same insolence
will breed a "silence treatment" of
freshmen that will be even more
injurious than a torn shirt or a
darkened eye.
The system which is •being inaugurated this year has been sanet:oned by the faculty and students
after a serious study of conditions
at Hopkins, and we believe it is
only necessary to communicate this
fact to the new men to insure their
co-operation in the step toward better spirit and class feeling. •
Another suggestion THE NEWSLETTER wishes to make concerns
the noun frequently used by new
men in referring to the Johns Hopkins University. We hear such
Phrases as, "It is a fine school,"
"Have you subscribed for the school
paper yet?" etc.
Hopkins is not a school, in the
definite meaning of that word, and
the freshman who persists in calling it so appears childish in the
estimation of those who understand

and use the dignified and correct
university. Remember that vou are
college men attending a university.
The third suggestion is offered
to avoid the recurrence of the anc:ent joke- on Professor Brush.
Each year some freshman, reading
in the University circular, discovers
that the French language is taught
by Professor Brush. Immediately
he calls up a companion and tells
him it is a good thing the professor
does not teach German, for then he
would be called Herr Brush. And
then the epidemic of that "joke"
passes over the University, annoy:ng three upper classes who have
reached the sage of shedding- tears
over the words. The "joke," we
may add, is well known. It was
discoyered in 1873, and has been
told at the Maryland Theatre.
And so THE NEWS-LETTER, askng the carrying out of these reattests, bids the Class of 1918 a
hearty welcome.
Select Rhodes Scholar New Way.

A change of system in the method
of selecting the Rhodes scholars to
Oxford University has been announced to Am e r lean colleges.
Hitherto, scholars haYe been elected
in all states in two successive years,
while in each recurring third year
none was chosen. The new system
divides the forty-eight states into
groups, and the groups are to be
alternated in the presentation of
candidates. The next qualifying
examination will be held in all states
on October 5 and 6, 1915. The
scholarships carry $1,500 a year,
and are tenable for three years.

AT OTHER COLLEGES
Lehigh Practicing Lacrosse.
The Lehigh lacrosse coaches arc
holding fall practice, primarily to
teach new men the rudiments of the
game. Many of the last-year men
took advantage of this time and reported also.
These practices are to be held
every Tuesday, Wednesday and
Friday afternoon of each week and
all candidates for the team, whether
new or old, have been ordered out.
This year 'the champions of the
Intercollegiate Lacrosse League
probably will be invited by the American Amateur Athletic League to the
Panama Exposition at San Francis°. The manner of choosing the
team has not yet been decided. It
is quite evident, however, that in
order to have a chance to go, Lehigh must at least .be champions of
this division.—The Brown and
White.

Actual class, work at Homewood
began Tuesday, when the engineering faculty and -third and fourth
year students organ:zed in the new

There were no ceremonies, but
the handful of men who will work
there for the year felt that they
were beginning something new in

Estate.

the students Nvill derive a great

surrendered the building to the

longer will be a dream, but a reality.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER

6

DR. REMSEN RETURNS

12,1914.

HIS TIMELY FIELD GOAL IN LAST MINUTE OF GAME BEAT STEVENS

Dr. Abercrombie Writes Complete Description of Gymnasium and Athletic
Work for the Alumni Magazine.

President-Emeritus of University Visited
New Zealand When War Spoiled
Interesting Australian Trip.

Dr. Ira Remsen, president-emeritus of the University, returned on
Friday night with Mrs. Remsen
from a long trip across the globe.
He started on July 22 for Australia, leaving San Francisco at the
end of the month. While on the
Pacific, however, the European war
broke out, and the sessions of the
British Association for the Advancement of Science, which he was
to have attended in Sydney, Australia, were canceled. Dr. and Mrs.
Remsen did not learn of the war
until they touched port some time
after actual fighting had begun.
As the boat they were on was
requisitioned at Wellington, New
Zealand, Dr. Remsen decided not to
go on to Australia. He remained
about a month, during which time
he saw much of the country and
had opportunity to study the people
and customs of this strange, remote
land.
"New Zealand is surprisingly up
to date," Dr. Remsen said. "It is
all quite modern, and as for war
news, well, we got plenty of it. I
find that I am about as well posted
as if I had been in the United States
all the time. The New Zealanders
are very patriotic. They, of course,
can see but one result of the war.
Interest in the conflict was intense,
and every .man seemed willing to
go to the front if necessary.
"There is a small standing army,
but I do not think it is especially
important."

TELLS OF GYMNASIUM WORK

Yell Practices This Week.

President Thomas F. Troxell, of
the General Athletic Association,
will call a mass-meeting (probably
two) this week, the object of which
is primarily to give new men practice in the Hopkins yells and songs.
The dates will be posted on the bulletin board.
The cheering stand on Saturday
did well under Leader Jack DeWitt,
but improvement will be needed.
Of course, it is impossible to expect immediate perfection in the
more complicated "figures," and for
this reason the defects of last week
may be overlooked.
One of the "freshman regulations" requires immediate mastery
of the yells and songs, and, inasmuch as the upper classmen will arrange meetings to afford practice,
it is hoped everyone will contribute
his voice to the good cause.
At the practice last week Bill
Merrick, Bob Nelson and Jack DeWitt alternated in leading the yells.

A Reminder of Hopkins Days.

Freshmen who have already begun to groan under the burden of
compulsory gymnasium work will
doubtless be interested in Dr. Abercrombie's article, "The Department
of the Gymnasium," published in
the June number of the Alumni
Illaga47ine. The history of the departrnent, its control, the position
it has occupied at -various times
M relation to the other University
units and a description of its work
are given in brief, and closely related matters of athletic interest
are then discussed.
In particular, Dr. Abercrombie
explains the machinery by which
the business of the Athletic Association is transacted. A diagram is
given, showing the relative powers
of each of the individuals or boards
connected W 1 al gymnasium and
athletic team control. Great emphasis is laid upon the fact that the
desire of the trustees and faculty
is to encourage student control of
athletic affairs, although veto power
must of necessity be given to the
faculty, through the person of the
director of the gymnasium. Under
ordinary circumstances, however,
this official acts only in the capacity
of adviser, or a court of appeals
when any dispute arises.
A paragraph .in the latter part of
the article discusses the question of
medical attention .for.those who are
seriously injured while representing the University on any athletic
team. The writer then deals with
the Hopkins policy in regard to
graduate and professional coaching,
and closes. with a list of names of
the men who compose the present
Athletic Board and management of
the teams.

'THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, OCTOBER 12, 1914.
HARVARD GREETS FRESH1ES

'MEDICAL SCHOOL CELEBRATES

The "Lampoon's" Story of the Opening
Reception to New Men Sounds
Very, Very Familiar.

Anniversaries Observed Last Week Bring
Host of Famous Doctors and Nurses.
Dr.Goodnow's First Appearance.

Here is the program—is hasn't
varied a jot for zoo years.
The• room is packed to suffocation with excited young men in new
shoes, all trying to look dignified,
exclusive and athletic.
Bumf (President of Student
Council)—Fellers [cheers and applause], I'm glad to see y' all.
[Fuddled sophomore in rear, who
has come in to get the refreshments, "Raise him, somebody."] I
hope you like the dear old place
[sobs] ; I hope you'll all go out
for something. [Several go out
for air.] Yes, it pays to be active;
take Blifkins, for example. [Tells
the third oldest story in captivity,
and everyone roars with laughter.]
It is now my pleasure to interduce
Captain Gumf of the Eleven. [Violent cheering.]
Captain Gumf (swallowing several lumps in quick succession)—
Fellers [mad tumult and cries of
"Hear," "Beer" and "Bravo"]—I
repeat, Fellers [another outbreak],
I'm not a speechmaker [applause],
but I-hope-we'll go-to-Nooaven-an'beatell-outa-Yale.
[Pandemonium!]
The Glee Club, which has suddenly appeared from somewhere,
and which tries to look as if it were
present by mere chance, .obliges
with the new one, "Australia, Bum,
Bum, Bum," and follows it up with
"Em, Zwei, Drei." [Modest applause.]
Bumf—Fellers, the next speaker
is Mr. Lumf, of the Crimson.
Lumf arises amid catcalls, does a
Dan'l-Webster pose, and awaits applause. He begins,"My dear young
friends [silence; several dear young
friends depart via the window]. It
is indeed a rare pleasure to see your
smiling and boyish countenances,
as yet unmarked by the cares we
editors know. I am unprepared to
do this occasion justice; I was called
upon at the last minute to come before you; so I have no speech
ready. [Consults typewritten manuscript of his speech and and proceeds.]
"This brings me to point number
two which, as I have forgotten it,
I will not consider. [Genuine ap„plause.]
"But on this happy occasion I
must tell a funny story. As I was
sitting last night in my sanctum
tankorum, making up the Crimson
[impressive but fruitless pause]
with the aid of a bottle of Bud, a
pair of shears, some paste and a
week-old Transcript, a man entered,
very excited, and asked: 'Can I
subscribe for the Crimson here?'
Quick as a flash I retorted: 'Maybe
so, and then again, maybe not.'
We both laughed heartily at my
little sally. [Pause—Lumf titters;
others remain grimly silent.]

A host of alumni of the Johns
Hopkins M edica 1 School and
Nurses' Training School returned
to Baltimore last week to take part
(in the twenty-fifth anniversary Celebration of the hospital and the
twenty-fifth anniversary of the
Medical School.
Distinguished
medical men of this country and
Europe attended the exercises, and
clinics, banquets and the Huerta
lectures added to the scientific importance of the celebration.
At a public meeting held in the
Lyric on the opening day of the
celebration, President Goodnovv
made his first public appearance in
Baltimore. In a clear and concise
address, Dr. Goodnow made an exceedingly agreeable impression upon
the audience. No reference to any
plans which he may have for his
work at the University was made.
Disappointment was expressed
because of the inability of Sir William Osler, of Oxford, honorary
professor of medicine at Hopkins,
to attend. He was detained in England on account of the war.
More than five hundred alumni of
the Medical School and more than
two hundred of the graduates of
the Training School for Nurses attended the celebration.

Dr. Remsen Visits Washington.

THE NEWS-LETTER reprints the
following clipping from the University of Washington Daily:
"Dr.Ira Remsen,the distinguished
research chemist of Baltimore, and
president emeritus of Johns Hopkins University, visited the University of Washington on his return
from an international convention of
scientists in New Zeland. He was
the guest of President Landes, and
called on several of the members
of the faculty who came from Johns
Hopkins (Dean A. S. Haggett, Dr.
Horace Byers, Dr. P. J. Frein, Dr.
George M. Janes and Dr. L. E.
Wear).”

October io, 1914.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR—What do you think of the
following war poem?
When old von Kluck to England goes,
You'll see that land in its death throes.
He will grab the English by the collar,
And won't John Bull put up some holler!
Tommy Atkins will start on a run
When he sees in the distance the German siege gun.
Ask them in London Town today
The name of the general that will have
full sway
If Deutschland succeeds in winning the
fray;
And as one voice you will hear them
say:
"It's the wizard that led us a merry
dance
Through the hills and valleys of dear
old France.
For when we thought that he was lost
We found he had his fingers crossed,
And this old buck is Herr von Kluck!"

Yours,

L. S.

S." as it intends to maintain neutrality
during the European war—Ed.]

Seeing and Hearing.
"Did you see the shot fired?" was
the question of an Irishman called as
a witness in a trial once had in
Kansas City.
"I did not," was the Celt's response, "but I heard it foired."
"The evidence is not satisfactory," sternly announced the presiding magistrate. "Step down."
This legal finding was evidently
not precisely to the liking of the
Irishman, for no sooner had he left
the stand and had turned his back
than he gave way to a somewhat
derisive laugh. This had the effect
of arousing in turn the judge's ire,
and he immediately recalled the offender.
"How dare you show such contempt of court?" demanded his
honor. "What do you mean by
laughing in that manner?"
"Did your honor see me laugh?"
asked the Irishman, in a most respectful tone.
"No, but I distinctly heard you
laugh," said the magistrate.
A twinkle canie into the eyes of
the witness. "Such evidence is not
satisfactory, your honor," said he
quietly. Whereupon everyone, including the judge, laughed.
